title: Basic Math Operations
simplifierConcept:
C# is like a super-powered calculator! You can do math with variables using familiar operators:

• + (addition): 5 + 3 = 8
• - (subtraction): 10 - 4 = 6
• * (multiplication): 6 * 7 = 42 (we use * because × isn't on keyboards!)
• / (division): 20 / 4 = 5
• % (modulus - remainder): 10 % 3 = 1 (10 divided by 3 is 3 remainder 1)

The modulus (%) might seem weird, but it's super useful! Want to know if a number is even? If number % 2 equals 0, it's even!

C# follows the same order of operations you learned in school: PEMDAS (Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication/Division, Addition/Subtraction).

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: WATCH OUT! When dividing two integers, C# gives you an INTEGER result. 10/3 = 3 (not 3.333...). The decimal part is thrown away!
The % operator gives you the REMAINDER after division. 10 % 3 = 1 because 10 ÷ 3 = 3 with 1 left over.
Use ( ) to control order! 5 + 3 * 2 = 11, but (5 + 3) * 2 = 16. Parentheses are calculated first!

challenge.instructions:
Create a program that calculates the area and perimeter of a rectangle!

1. Create 'int' variables for length (8) and width (5)
2. Calculate area (length × width)
3. Calculate perimeter (2 × length + 2 × width)
4. Display both results with labels

Bonus: Try using parentheses to make your perimeter calculation clearer!
challenge.hint: Area = length × width. Perimeter = 2×length + 2×width (or 2×(length+width) with parentheses!). Use the * operator for multiplication!
commonStickingPoints: Using 'x' or '×' for multiplication: In C#, you MUST use the asterisk (*). 5 * 3, not 5 x 3!
Integer division surprise: 7 / 2 gives you 3, not 3.5! The decimal part disappears with int division.
Forgetting order of operations: 2 * length + 2 * width works, but 2 * (length + width) is clearer!
